revision.text:
[[Image:MicrosoftBKSelft2000.JPG|right|120px]]
'''Microsoft Bookshelf''' was a [[Reference work|reference]] collection introduced in 1987 as part of [[Microsoft]]'s extensive work in promoting [[CD-ROM]] technology as a distribution medium for [[electronic publishing]]. The original [[MS-DOS]] version showcased the massive storage capacity of CD-ROM technology, and was accessed while the user was using one of 13 different word processor programs that Bookshelf supported. Subsequent versions were produced for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and became a commercial success as part of the [[Microsoft Home]] brand. It was often bundled with [[personal computer]]s as a cheaper alternative to the [[Microsoft Encarta|Encarta Suite]]. The Encarta Deluxe Suite / Reference Library versions also bundled Bookshelf.
==Content== Microsoft Bookshelf was discontinued in 2000. In later editions of the Encarta suite (Encarta 2000 and onwards), Bookshelf was replaced with a dedicated ''Encarta Dictionary'', a superset of the printed edition. There has been some controversy over the decision, since the dictionary lacks the other books provided in Bookshelf which many found to be a useful reference, such as the dictionary of quotations (replaced with a quotations section in ''Encarta'' that links to relevant articles and people) and the Internet Directory, although the directory is now a [[wikt:moot point|moot point]] since many of the sites listed in offline directories no longer exist.
The original 1987 edition contained ''[[Roget's Thesaurus|The Original Roget's Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases]]'', ''[[The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]]'', [[World Almanac]] and Book of Facts, [[Bartlett's Familiar Quotations]], [[The Chicago Manual of Style]] (13th Edition), the U.S. ZIP Code Directory, Houghton Mifflin Usage Alert, [[Houghton Mifflin]] Spelling Verifier and Corrector, Business Information Sources, and Forms and Letters.<ref name="Bookshelf 87">{{cite web|title=Computers for Lawyers|work=Chapter 25|first=Paul|last=Bernstein|publisher=ATLA Press 1992 {{ISBN|0-941916-64-2}}|year=1992|isbn=0-941916-64-2|accessdate=2006-04-18|url=http://www.cyberbarassociation.net/cfl/book/chpt25.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060504152218/http://www.cyberbarassociation.net/cfl/book/chpt25.htm|archivedate=2006-05-04|df=}}</ref> Titles in non-US versions of Bookshelf were different. For example, the 1997 UK edition included the Chambers Dictionary, Bloomsbury Treasury of Quotations, and Hutchinson Concise Encyclopedia.<ref>[http://www.pcpro.co.uk/reviews/software/722/bookshelf-british-reference-collection Bookshelf British Reference Collection] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019005540/http://www.pcpro.co.uk/reviews/software/722/bookshelf-british-reference-collection |date=2009-10-19 }}</ref>
The Windows release of Bookshelf added a number of new reference titles, including ''The Concise [[Columbia Encyclopedia]]'' and an [[Web directory|Internet Directory]]. Other titles were added and some were dropped in subsequent years. By 1994, the [[English language|English-language]] version also contained the ''[[Columbia Dictionary of Quotations]]''; ''The Concise [[Columbia Encyclopedia]]''; the ''[[Hammond Intermediate World Atlas]]''; and ''[[The People's Chronology]]''.<ref name="Bookshelf 94">{{cite web |title=Microsoft Bookshelf 1994 |first=Birger|last=Nielsen|work=The Tea Page |url=http://www.246.dk/teamsb94.html|year=2006|accessdate=2006-04-18}}</ref> By 2000, the collection came to include the ''[[Encarta]] Desk Encyclopedia'', the ''Encarta Desk Atlas'', the ''Encarta Style Guide'' and a specialized ''Computer and Internet Dictionary'' by [[Microsoft Press]].
==Technology==
===Bookshelf 1.0 engine=== Bookshelf 1.0 used a [[Proprietary software|proprietary]] [[hypertext]] engine that Microsoft acquired when it bought the company Cytation in 1986.<ref name="Microsoft 1980s">{{cite web |title=A History of the Personal Computer: The People and the Technology |work=Chapter 12 Microsoft in the 1980s |first=Roy|last=Allan|publisher=Allan Publishing 2001 {{ISBN|0-9689108-0-7}} |year=2001 |isbn=0-9689108-0-7|accessdate=2006-04-18 |url=http://www.retrocomputing.net/info/allan/eBook12.pdf }}</ref> Also used for Microsoft Stat Pack and Microsoft Small Business Consultant, it was a [[Terminate and Stay Resident]] (TSR) program that ran alongside a dominant program, unbeknownst to the dominant program. Like Apple's similar [[Hypercard]] reader, Bookshelf engine's files used a single [[compound document]], containing large numbers of subdocuments ("cards" or "articles"). They both differ from current browsers which normally treat each "page" or "article" as a separate file.
Though similar to Apple's [[Hypercard]] reader in many ways, the Bookshelf engine had several key differences. Unlike Hypercard files, Bookshelf files required compilation and complex markup codes. This made the files more difficult to pirate, addressing a key concern of early electronic publishers. Furthermore, Bookshelf's engine was designed to run as fast as possible on slow first-generation [[CD-ROM]] drives, some of which required as much as a half-second to move the drive head. Such hardware constraints made Hypercard impractical for high-capacity CD-ROMs.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Bookshelf also had full text searching capability, which made it easy to find needed information.
===Bookshelf 2.0 engine=== Collaborating with [[DuPont]], the Microsoft CD-ROM division developed a [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] version of its engine for applications as diverse as [[Document management system|document management]], [[online help]], and a CD-ROM [[encyclopedia]]. In a [[skunkworks project]], these developers worked secretly with Multimedia Division developers so that the engine would be usable for more ambitious multimedia applications. Thus they integrated a multimedia [[markup language]], [[full text search]], and extensibility using [[software componentry|software objects]],<ref name="Viewer 2.0">{{cite book| title=Microsoft Multimedia Viewer How-To Cd: Create Exciting Multimedia With Video, Animation, Music, and Speech for Windows/Book and Cd| last=Pruitt|first=Stephen|publisher=Waite Group Pr|isbn=1-878739-60-3}}</ref> all of which are commonplace in modern internet browsing.
In 1992, Microsoft started selling the Bookshelf engine to third-party developers, marketing the product as Microsoft Multimedia Viewer. The idea was that such a tool would help a burgeoning growth of CD-ROM titles that would spur demand for Windows. Although the engine had multimedia capabilities that would not be matched by Web browsers until the late 1990s, Microsoft Viewer did not enjoy commercial success as a standalone product. However, Microsoft continued to use the engine for its [[Encarta]] and [[WinHelp]] applications, though the multimedia functions are rarely used in Windows help files.
===Viewer 3.0=== In 1993, the developers who were working on the next generation viewer were moved to the [[Cairo (operating system)|Cairo systems group]] which was charged with delivering [[Bill Gates]]' 'vision' of 'Information at your fingertips'. This advanced browser was a fully componentized application using what are now known as [[Component Object Model]] objects, designed for hypermedia browsing across large networks and whose main competitor was thought to be [[Lotus Notes]]. Long before Netscape appeared, this team, known as the WEB (web enhanced browser) team had already shipped a network capable hypertext browser capable of doing everything that HTML browsers would not be able to do until the turn of the century. Nearly all technologies of Cairo shipped. The WEB browser was not one of them, though it influenced the design of many other common Microsoft technologies.
==Reception== ''[[Byte (magazine)|BYTE]]'' in 1989 listed Microsoft Bookshelf as among the "Excellence" winners of the BYTE Awards, stating that it "is the first substantial application of CD-ROM technology" and "a harbinger of personal library systems to come".<ref name="byte198901">{{Cite magazine |date=January 1989 |title=The BYTE Awards |url=https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1989-01/1989_01_BYTE_14-01_PC_Communications_and_Annual_Awards_and_Digitizing_Tablets#page/n371/mode/2up |magazine=BYTE |page=327}}</ref>
==Versions== * Versions for DOS/Windows/Mac: ** Bookshelf 1987 Edition for MS-DOS ** Bookshelf 1.0 (March 18, 1991) ** Bookshelf 1991 Edition (October 1991) ** Bookshelf 1992 Edition ** Bookshelf 1993 Edition (Not For Retail Sale, bundled with Tandy Sensation!) ** Bookshelf '94 ** Bookshelf '95 ** Bookshelf British Reference Collection (BRC) ** Bookshelf 1996-'97 Edition (Last version for Windows 3.1) <ref>[http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/press/1996/apr96/bksh96pr.mspx Bookshelf 1996-97 Edition Press Release]</ref> ** Bookshelf 98 (Last version for Macintosh) ** Bookshelf 99 ** Bookshelf 2000 (last English version for Windows) ** Bookshelf 3.0 Japanese (last version for Windows)
===US version contents===
{| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 80%; border: gray solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse; text-align: center; width: auto; table-layout: fixed;" |- style="background: #ececec;" ! style="width: 12em" | Package ! The People's Chronology ! Columbia Dictionary of Quotations ! The Concise Columbia Encyclopedia Third Edition ! Hammond World Atlas ! Internet Directory 95 ! Encarta Grammar & Style Guide ! Computer & Internet Dictionary |- ! style="text-align: center; background: #ececec;" | Bookshelf 2000 ! The American Heritage Dictionary, 3rd Ed. ! Roget's Thesaurus ! Encarta 2000 New World Almanac ! Encarta 2000 New World Timeline ! Columbia Dictionary of Quotations ! Encarta 2000 Desk Encyclopedia ! Encarta 2000 Desk World Atlas ! ! Encarta Manual of Style & Usage ! Computer & Internet Dictionary |}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use South African English|date=August 2012}} '''''R v Mataung'''''<ref>1953 (4) SA 35 (O).</ref> is an important case in [[South African law]], heard and decided in the Orange Free State Provincial Division on 13 August 1953. Brink J wrote the judgment; Van Blerk J concurred.
== Facts == The accused had pleaded guilty to and been convicted of [[arson]], in that he had set alight a grass hut.
== Judgment == On review, the Orange Free State Provincial Division held that, in the absence of evidence that the hut was of an immovable nature, the conviction and the sentence should be set aside. The court referred to and applied the decision of Innes CJ in ''[[R v Mabula]]'',<ref>1927 AD 161.</ref> which held that the [[property]] affected had to have been [[immovable property]] for the definition of arson to be met.
== See also == * [[R v Soqokomashe]] * [[Arson]] * [[Crime in South Africa]] * [[Law of South Africa]]
== References == === Case law === * ''[[R v Mabula]]'' 1927 AD 161. * ''R v Mataung'' 1953 (4) SA 35 (O).
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1953 in South African law]] [[Category:1953 in case law]] [[Category:Arson in Africa]]
{{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

revision.text:
Many [[countries]] and national [[census]]es currently enumerate or have previously enumerated their [[populations]] by [[Race (human classification)|race]], [[ethnicity]], [[nationality]], or a combination of these characteristics.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/race/000_About/002_03-godeeper.htm |title=RACE — The Power of an Illusion . Go Deeper |publisher=PBS |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ND1__tXqfDYC&pg=PT11&lpg=PT11&dq=%22ann+morning%22+soviet+union&source=bl&ots=WbMj8W1tXU&sig=DIK7OUqJd8CoggdrvsFLOniV6d8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ovrCUcXJMKr1iwKYuIHACw&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAw |title=Ethnicity — Steve Fenton — Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-06-20}} Different countries have different classifications and census options for race and ethnicity/nationality which are not comparable with data from other countries.{{cite web|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/sconcerns/popchar/Morning.pdf |title=Approaches To Racial And Ethnic Classification |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}} In addition, many of the race and ethnicity concepts that appear on national censuses worldwide have their origins in [[Europe]] or in the views of [[Europeans]], rather than in the views of the locals of these countries.{{cite web|title=Census and identity: The Politics of Race, Ethnicity and Language in National Censuses|url=http://catdir.loc.gov/catdir/samples/cam031/2001037352.pdf|publisher=Cambridge University|accessdate=2 December 2012|author1=David I. Kertzer |author2=Dominique Arel }} [[File:Ethnicity and race in censuses.png|thumb|500px|Map showing countries where the ethnicity or race of people was enumerated in at least one census since 1991.]] ==Abkhazia== People in [[Abkhazia]] (when it was still a part of the [[Russian Empire]]) were enumerated by [[native tongue]] [[1897 census|in the 1897 Russian Empire Census]].{{cite web|url=http://demoscope.ru/weekly/ssp/rus_lan_97_uezd_eng.php |title=Demoscope Weekly - Annex. Statistical indicators reference |publisher=Demoscope.ru |date=2012-09-16 |accessdate=2012-09-21}}{{cite web|url=http://demoscope.ru/weekly/ssp/rus_rel_97.php?reg=0 |title=Демоскоп Weekly - Приложение. Справочник статистических показателей |publisher=Demoscope.ru |date= |accessdate=2012-09-21}} In addition to the Soviet Union enumerating people by ethnicity for its entire existence,{{cite web|url=http://demoscope.ru/weekly/ssp/census_types.php?ct=6 |title=Приложение Демоскопа Weekly |publisher=Demoscope.ru |date=2013-01-15 |accessdate=2013-03-21}} the [[International recognition of Abkhazia|partially recognized state]] of [[Abkhazia]] also enumerated people by ethnicity in its post-Soviet censuses of 2003{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/abkhazia-ethnic2003.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Abkhazia 2003 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} and 2011.{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/abkhazia-ethnic2011.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Abkhazia 2011 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} ==Afghanistan== Prior to 2010, [[Afghanistan]] had not held a census since 1979 due to the wars and conflicts that have occurred there over those three decades (since the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]] in 1979).{{cite web|url=http://cso.gov.af/Content/files/Population.pdf|title=Afghanistan Statistical Yearbook 2009-10}} ==Albania== [[Albania]] enumerated people by ethnicity in 1955,{{cite web|title=Ethnicity: A Review of Data Collection and Dissemination|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/sconcerns/popchar/Ethnicitypaper.pdf|publisher=United Nations Statistics Division|accessdate=30 November 2012|date=August 2003}} 1989,{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/albania-ethnic1989.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Albania 1989 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} and 2011.{{cite web|author=Gezim Krasniqi |url=http://www.citsee.eu/blog/politics-numbers-and-identity-albania |title=Natitonality and census in Albania |publisher=Citsee.Eu |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}}{{cite web|url=http://census.al/Resources/Data/Census2011/PES%20Questionnaire%20ENG.pdf|title=Albania Post Enumeration Survey|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711042241/http://census.al/Resources/Data/Census2011/PES%20Questionnaire%20ENG.pdf|archivedate=July 11, 2012|date=2011}} The 2011 Albanian census also enumerated people by language used and by their religious beliefs. ==Angola== [[File:Angola Ethnic map 1970.svg|thumb|right|100px|Ethnic composition of Angola in 1970]] The [[Portugal|Portuguese]] asked about race in colonial censuses when they controlled Angola, and they provided three options: White, Mestizo, or African/Black. Africans had to then pick either "Assimilado" (assimilated) or "Indigenato" (indigenous).{{cite web|url=http://institutionalizedethnicity.net/country-narratives/angola/ |title=Angola |publisher=Institutionalized Ethnicity |date= |accessdate=2012-09-22}} Angola has not used any racial categories since its independence in 1975. Tribe and language for Africans were recorded only in 1950 and 1960. ==Argentina== Argentina enumerated its population by their country of birth from 1869 to the present day.{{cite web|url=http://www.indec.gov.ar/webcenso/aquisecuenta/Aqui12.pdf|title=Tendencias recientes de la Inmigración internacional |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824231326/http://www.indec.gov.ar/webcenso/aquisecuenta/aqui12.pdf|archivedate=August 24, 2007|date=February 2004 |issn= 0329-7586|publisher=Indec}} ==Armenia== People in Armenia (when it was still a part of the [[Russian Empire]]) were enumerated by native tongue [[1897 census|in the 1897 Russian Empire Census]]. In addition to the Soviet Union enumerating people by ethnicity for its entire existence, [[Armenia]] also enumerated people by ethnicity in its post-Soviet censuses of 2001{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/armenia-ethnic2001.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Armenia 2001 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} and 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.armstat.am/file/doc/99465273.pdf|title=CENSUS PROGRAMME (CONTENT OF QUESTIONNAIRE) 2011 CENSUS OF THE REPUBLIC OF ARMENIA }} ==Australia== Australia enumerated its population by ''race'' between 1911 and 1966, by ''racial origin'' in 1971 and 1976, by ''ethnic'' origin in 1981, and by ''ancestry'' since 1986.{{cite web|url=http://abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/2071.0Feature+Article2July+2011 |title=2071.0 - Reflecting a Nation: Stories from the 2011 Census, July 2011 |publisher=Abs.gov.au |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2013-04-06}} ==Azerbaijan== [[File:Azerbaijan ethnic 2003.png|thumb|right|100px|Ethnic composition of Azerbaijan in 2003.]] People in Azerbaijan (when it was still a part of the [[Russian Empire]]) were enumerated by native tongue [[1897 census|in the 1897 Russian Empire Census]]. In addition to the Soviet Union enumerating people by ethnicity for its entire existence, [[Azerbaijan]] also enumerated people by ethnicity in its post-Soviet censuses of 1999{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/azerbaijan-ethnic1999.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Azerbaijan 1999 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} and 2009.{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/azerbaijan-ethnic2009.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Azerbaijan 2009 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date=1971-04-07 |accessdate=2013-03-21}} ==Bahamas== The population of the [[Bahamas]] was enumerated by ethnicity in 1953. ==Bahrain== [[Bahrain]] enumerated people by ethnicity in 1965 and 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.census2010.gov.bh/results_en.php |title=Bahraini Census 2010 - تعداد السكــان العام للبحريــن 2010 |publisher=Census2010.gov.bh |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} The 2010 Bahrain census also enumerated people by their religious beliefs. ==Bangladesh== [[British India]] (which Bangladesh was a part of) enumerated its population by race between 1872 and 1941.{{cite web|url=http://censusindia.gov.in/Data_Products/Library/Indian_perceptive_link/Census_Terms_link/censusterms.html |title=Census of India - Census Terms |publisher=Censusindia.gov.in |date= |accessdate=2013-06-10}} ==Barbados== The population of [[Barbados]] was enumerated by ethnicity in 1946, 1960, 1970, and 1980. ==Belarus== [[File:Belarusians in Belarus 2009.png|thumb|right|100px|[[Belarusians]] as a percentage of the total population in Belarus in 2009 (note: map is in Ukrainian).]] People in Belarus (when it was still a part of the [[Russian Empire]]) were enumerated by native tongue [[1897 census|in the 1897 Russian Empire Census]]. In addition to the Soviet Union enumerating people by ethnicity for its entire existence, [[Belarus]] also enumerated people by ethnicity in its post-Soviet censuses of 1999{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/belarus-ethnic1999.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Belarus 1999 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} and 2009.{{cite web|url=http://pop-stat.mashke.org/belarus-ethnic2009.htm |title=Ethnic composition of Belarus 2009 |publisher=Pop-stat.mashke.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} ==Belize== Back when [[Belize]] was [[British Honduras]], it enumerated people by ethnicity in 1946. Since gaining independence, Belize has enumerated people by ethnicity from 1980 all the way up to its most recent census in 2010. ==Benin== The people in [[Benin]] were enumerated by ethnicity in 1979 and 1992. ==Bermuda== The people of [[Bermuda]] were enumerated by ethnicity since at least 1950 all the way up to the present day.{{cite web|author=Keith Archibald Forbes |url=http://www.bermuda-online.org/population.htm |title=Bermuda's Population and local Expatriate Organizations |publisher=Bermuda-online.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} ==Bolivia== [[File:Pueblos originarios de Bolivia.png|thumb|right|100px|Ethnic composition of Bolivia.]] [[Bolivia]] enumerated people by ethnicity in 1950, 2001,{{cite web|author=CEPAL - Naciones Unidas |url=http://www.eclac.org/cgi-bin/getProd.asp?xml=/publicaciones/xml/3/23263/P23263.xml&xsl=/celade/tpl/p9f.xsl&base=/celade/tpl/top-bottom.xsl |title=CEPAL - Los pueblos indígenas de Bolivia: diagnóstico sociodemográfico a partir del censo del 2001 |publisher=Eclac.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} and 2012.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/bolivias-census-omits-mestizo-category-17779349#.ULm6AJtQAak |title=Bolivia's Census Omits 'Mestizo' as Category - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-21}} The 2012 census included 40 ethnic group options. However, it did not include [[Mestizo]] as an option, which critics of current [[Bolivian President]] [[Evo Morales]] say was because he wants more Bolivians to identify as one of the indigenous groups in order to lend more legitimacy to his indigenous-friendly policies.
'''Data from the census in 2012'''{{cite web|title=Census in Bolivia|url=http://www.ine.gob.bo:8081/censo2012/PDF/resultadosCPV2012.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209134921/http://www.ine.gob.bo:8081/censo2012/PDF/resultadosCPV2012.pdf|archivedate=2014-02-09|df=}}
